deliberation: Considered the rhetorical questions and the phrase 'arm of the LORD.' The questions are rhetorical but not in themselves figurative. 'Arm of the LORD' is a standard anthropomorphic/metonymic expression for God's power and saving action, thus figurative.

instances.english_text: Upon whom has the arm of the LORD been revealed?
target: God's effective power and saving intervention
vehicle: human body part associated with strength
ground: strength, capability to act, exerted force
posture: speaker marveling that God's power is hidden in an unlikely form
instances.explanation: The 'arm of the LORD' uses a human limb as a metonymy for God's powerful, effective action in history.

deliberation: Examined the growth imagery and the statements about lack of beauty. Two explicit כ‑similes compare the servant’s emergence to plant growth in poor conditions. The lack-of-beauty statements are evaluative but essentially literal.

instances.english_text: For he has grown ... like a sapling before Him
ground: emergence in a protected yet lowly state
posture: speaker depicting the servant as unimpressive yet quietly growing under God's eye
instances.explanation: The servant’s early life is likened to a young plant shoot, highlighting his vulnerability and lack of outward impressiveness.

instances.english_text: and like a root out of arid ground
target: the servant’s unlikely emergence and survival
vehicle: שורש מארץ ציה (root out of dry ground)
ground: unexpected survival and growth in unpromising, harsh conditions
posture: speaker emphasizing how improbable and unpromising the servant’s origin appears
contrast between divine choice and human expectations
instances.explanation: Comparing the servant to a root in parched soil stresses how unlikely and precarious his rise seems, despite divine favor.

deliberation: Considered 'man of sorrows' and 'acquainted with disease' as possible characterizing metaphors, and the כ‑phrase about hiding the face. 'Man of sorrows' functions as a metaphorical designation; 'like one from whom faces are hidden' is a clear simile of social rejection.

instances.english_text: a man of suffering, familiar with disease
target: the servant’s identity as dominated by suffering
vehicle: 'man of X' construction with pains and sickness
person whose defining possession is affliction
ground: continuous exposure to, and saturation with, pain and illness
posture: speaker underscoring that suffering is not incidental but central to who he is
instances.explanation: Calling him 'a man of sorrows' with 'knowledge of sickness' metaphorically makes suffering his defining trait, not just an occasional experience.

instances.english_text: as one who hid his face from us / like one from whom people hide their faces
target: the way people respond to and socially reject the servant
vehicle: a person people turn away from and hide their faces from
encounter with something repulsive or shameful
ground: sense of shame, disgust, or unwillingness to acknowledge someone
posture: speaker highlighting the extremity of communal rejection and emotional distancing
instances.explanation: The comparison to someone from whom one hides the face pictures the servant as so despised that people refuse even visual contact.

deliberation: Considered whether 'bearing sickness' is literal or figurative. The collocation נשא/סבל + abstract nouns (our sicknesses, our pains) is a standard metaphor/idiom for carrying another’s burden or guilt. The judgments 'plagued, smitten by God' can be literal afflictions; the key figurative element is the bearing of others’ afflictions.

instances.hebrew_text: אָכֵן חֳלָיֵנוּ הוּא נָשָׂא וּמַכְאֹבֵינוּ סְבָלָם
instances.english_text: Yet it was our sickness that he was bearing, our suffering that he endured.
target: the servant’s assumption of others’ afflictions and guilt
vehicle: בָּאֵר / נָשָׂא, סָבַל (to bear, to carry) applied to sickness and pains
ground: taking on weight that properly belongs to another, relieving them of it
transfer and endurance of what crushes others
posture: speaker correcting the misjudgment by revealing a hidden vicarious function in his suffering
instances.explanation: Describing 'our sicknesses' and 'our pains' as things he 'bears' and 'carries' metaphorically presents them as a load he shoulders on behalf of others.

deliberation: The verse is saturated with physical-injury and healing language applied to sins and peace. Rather than several unrelated images, it forms one integrated substitutionary metaphor: his bodily wounding and bruising produce the others’ moral and relational wholeness.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהוּא מְחֹלָל מִפְּשָׁעֵנוּ מְדֻכָּא מֵעֲוֹנֹתֵינוּ מוּסַר שְׁלוֹמֵנוּ עָלָיו וּבַחֲבֻרָתוֹ נִרְפָּא־לָנוּ
instances.english_text: But he was wounded because of our sins, crushed because of our iniquities. He bore the chastisement that made us whole, and by his bruises we were healed.
target: the others’ sins, peace, and restoration
human relationship with God and wholeness
vehicle: wounding, crushing, chastisement, bruises, and healing
ground: the idea that another’s painful treatment can result in someone else’s well-being, as pain leading to cure
harm incurred to remove what damages others
posture: speaker affirming a paradoxical, divinely arranged exchange where his suffering benefits others
instances.explanation: Physical terms—wounds, crushing, bruises, and healing—are used metaphorically for the way the servant’s suffering brings about the community’s moral and relational wholeness.

deliberation: Identified (1) an explicit animal simile 'like sheep we went astray,' (2) the common biblical metaphor of life/conduct as a 'way,' and (3) the now-familiar metaphor/idiom of iniquity being laid upon the servant as a burden.

instances.english_text: We all went astray like sheep
vehicle: grazing animals prone to wander without guidance
ground: aimless, unguarded wandering and vulnerability when separated from a guide
posture: speaker confessing the community’s foolishness and vulnerability in going astray
instances.explanation: The people’s moral deviation is likened to sheep straying from the flock, highlighting their folly and need for guidance.

instances.english_text: Each of us going our own way
target: each person’s chosen pattern of life and disobedience
vehicle: דֶּרֶךְ (way) as a route or path
ground: life conceived as a path one chooses and walks along
ongoing movement in a chosen direction
posture: speaker noting self-willed, divergent choices in the community
instances.explanation: Using 'way' for life-conduct metaphorically pictures each person as choosing and walking a distinct moral path.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיהוָה הִפְגִּיעַ בּוֹ אֵת עֲוֹן כֻּלָּנוּ
instances.english_text: And the LORD visited upon him the guilt of all of us
target: the total guilt of the community
vehicle: הִפְגִּיעַ בּוֹ (laid/caused to meet upon him)
placing a burden or impact upon someone
ground: guilt treated as something that can be transferred and made to rest on another
legal/moral liability conceptualized as a load
posture: speaker attributing to God the decisive act of transferring communal guilt to the servant
acceptance of divine allocation of guilt
instances.explanation: The iniquity of all is depicted as something God causes to strike or rest upon the servant, using burden-transfer imagery for vicarious bearing of guilt.

deliberation: The verse repeats twice that he does not open his mouth, then illustrates this with two explicit כ‑similes: sheep led to slaughter, ewe before shearers. These are distinct but closely parallel similes of silent submission.

instances.english_text: Like a sheep being led to slaughter
target: the servant’s silent, unresisting submission to unjust suffering
vehicle: docile animal taken to be killed
ground: passivity, lack of resistance, silence, and vulnerability when led to death
posture: speaker emphasizing the servant’s meekness under extreme injustice
instances.explanation: The servant’s submission is likened to a sheep led to slaughter, underlining his vulnerability and refusal to resist.

instances.english_text: Like a ewe, dumb before those who shear her
target: the servant’s quiet acceptance in the face of those who harm him
vehicle: רָחֵל לִפְנֵי גֹזְזֶיהָ נֶאֱלָמָה (a ewe silent before its shearers)
animal that offers no protest while being shorn
ground: silent endurance while being deprived or harmed
posture: speaker reinforcing the image of speechless endurance to stress its moral significance
instances.explanation: The comparison to a ewe silent before her shearers further underscores his refusal to protest or defend himself when wronged.

deliberation: Examined 'taken from oppression and judgment' as possibly idiomatic for an unjust legal process, likely still literal. The clearly figurative expression is 'cut off from the land of the living,' a conventional metaphor/idiom for dying.

instances.english_text: For he was cut off from the land of the living
target: the servant’s death and removal from the community
vehicle: נִגְזַר מֵאֶרֶץ חַיִּים (cut off from the land of the living)
ground: death conceived as being severed from the realm where the living dwell
posture: speaker stressing the severity and finality of his fate
instances.explanation: Death is depicted as being 'cut off' from the 'land of the living,' using territorial and cutting imagery for the termination of life.

deliberation: Considered whether 'among the wicked ... with the rich' formed a merism, but these are not conventional polar opposites; the line appears to state the social categories associated with his burial. Phrases about grave, injustice, and falsehood are straightforward and literal. No clear figurative device is required for the sense.

Looked at 'crush him by disease' as possibly figurative, but it can denote literal affliction. The key figurative elements are (1) his 'life' being made an 'offering for guilt,' importing sacrificial-cult imagery to interpret his death, and (2) 'the will of the LORD shall prosper in his hand,' where 'hand' functions as a metonymy for effective agency.

instances.english_text: If he made himself an offering for guilt (lit. if you set his life as a guilt-offering)
vehicle: cultic sacrificial animal offered for guilt
ground: his death functions like a sacrificial offering dealing with guilt
life given up to restore relationship with God
posture: speaker/the text interpreting his death within the cultic atonement framework
instances.explanation: His 'life' is described in terms of a specific cultic sacrifice, metaphorically construing his death as a guilt-offering.

instances.english_text: And the purpose of the LORD shall prosper in his hand
target: the effective execution of the LORD’s will through the servant
vehicle: instrument of human action and control
ground: the hand stands for the capacity to act and accomplish tasks
posture: speaker affirming that God’s plan will succeed through the servant’s agency
instances.explanation: The 'hand' is a metonymy for the servant’s active agency; God’s purpose is said to prosper 'in his hand,' i.e., through his effective action.

deliberation: Considered 'out of the travail of his soul' as possibly echoing birth-labor imagery, but the text mainly stresses suffering. The clearest recurring figurative device is 'he will bear their iniquities,' again using burden-bearing imagery for vicarious assumption of guilt.

instances.english_text: It is their punishment / iniquities that he bears
target: the many’s iniquities and the consequences they deserve
ground: treating guilt as a weight that can be placed on and endured by another
posture: speaker explaining how the righteous servant benefits many by assuming their burden
instances.explanation: The servant is said to 'bear' the many’s iniquities, using the image of carrying a load to depict his assumption of their guilt and punishment.

deliberation: Detected several distinct images: (1) dividing 'portion' and 'spoil' with the many/strong, a victory- and plunder-metaphor for exaltation; (2) 'he poured out his soul to death,' picturing life as liquid expended; (3) 'he bore the sin of many,' again the burden-bearing metaphor/idiom for vicarious guilt. 'Numbered with sinners' and 'made intercession' are more literal/legal-cultic in function.

instances.english_text: I will give him the many as his portion, he shall receive the multitude as his spoil (divide the spoil with the strong)
target: the servant’s post-suffering reward and exalted status
vindication and share in the redeemed
vehicle: portion and spoil division after battle
ground: receiving a rich share of what has been won through struggle, as a victor’s reward
posture: speaker depicting his exaltation in vivid, martial-reward terms
instances.explanation: His exaltation is cast in the imagery of a victorious warrior dividing plunder, symbolizing the honor and share he receives among the many and the strong.

instances.english_text: For he exposed / poured out his soul to death
vehicle: emptying out liquid from a container
ground: complete expenditure with nothing held back, resulting in emptiness or death
posture: speaker highlighting the extremity and voluntariness of his self-giving
instances.explanation: His 'soul' or life is portrayed as something poured out like liquid, emphasizing complete self-expenditure unto death.

instances.english_text: Whereas he bore the guilt/sin of the many
target: the many’s sins and their liability
ground: sin construed as something heavy that can be transferred to and carried by another
taking on what belongs to others
posture: speaker summarizing his vicarious role on behalf of sinners
instances.explanation: The many’s sin is depicted as a burden he 'bears,' continuing the recurring metaphor of guilt as a load assumed by the servant.
